diabetes.title: Diabetes Management
diabetes.brief: Complete guide to understanding and managing diabetes effectively.

content.heading: What is Diabetes?
content.text: A chronic condition where the body cannot regulate blood sugar properly, leading to high glucose levels.

content.heading: Why Does Diabetes Happen?
content.text: Type 1: Immune system destroys insulin-producing cells. Type 2: Body becomes resistant to insulin. Gestational: Temporary diabetes during pregnancy.

content.heading: Unique Fact
content.text: Eye doctors can sometimes detect diabetes during eye exams before symptoms appear.

content.heading: Risk Factors
content.text: Family history, obesity, sedentary lifestyle, high blood pressure, age over 40.

content.heading: Myth vs Fact
content.text: Myth: Eating sugar causes diabetes. Fact: While sugar contributes to weight gain, genetics and insulin resistance are main causes.

content.heading: Do's & Don'ts
content.text: ‚úî Do: Eat fiber-rich meals, stay active, check blood sugar. ‚úò Don‚Äôt: Skip meals, rely on junk food, or ignore regular check-ups.

content.heading: When to See a Doctor
content.text: If you experience excessive thirst, frequent urination, unexplained weight loss, or blurred vision.

content.heading: Daily Checklist
content.text: ‚úî Monitor blood sugar ‚úî Drink 2‚Äì3L water ‚úî Exercise 30 min ‚úî Eat balanced meals ‚úî Get 7‚Äì8 hrs sleep

heart-health.title: Heart Health
heart-health.brief: Smart lifestyle tips to keep your heart strong and disease-free.

content.heading: What is Heart Health?
content.text: A healthy heart pumps blood efficiently to the body, maintaining energy and organ function.

content.heading: Why Heart Disease Happens?
content.text: Plaque buildup in arteries, high blood pressure, stress, obesity, and smoking.

content.heading: Unique Fact
content.text: Your heart beats over 100,000 times a day ‚Äî about 3 billion times in a lifetime.

content.heading: Risk Factors
content.text: Unhealthy diet, smoking, family history, high cholesterol, stress.

content.heading: Myth vs Fact
content.text: Myth: Heart disease only affects old people. Fact: It can affect younger adults too, especially with poor lifestyle.

content.heading: Do's & Don'ts
content.text: ‚úî Do: Eat omega-3 foods, exercise, manage stress. ‚úò Don‚Äôt: Smoke, overeat processed food, or ignore symptoms.

content.heading: When to See a Doctor
content.text: If you feel chest pain, shortness of breath, dizziness, or irregular heartbeat.

content.heading: Daily Checklist
content.text: ‚úî 30 min walk ‚úî Eat fruits & veggies ‚úî Control salt ‚úî Sleep 7 hrs ‚úî Stay stress-free

mental-wellness.title: Mental Wellness
mental-wellness.brief: Tips for emotional balance, stress management, and healthy mindset.

content.heading: What is Mental Wellness?
content.text: A state of emotional stability where you can handle stress, stay positive, and live productively.

content.heading: Why It Matters?
content.text: Good mental health improves physical health, relationships, and productivity.

content.heading: Unique Fact
content.text: Gratitude journaling for just 5 minutes daily can increase happiness by 10% long-term.

content.heading: Risk Factors
content.text: Chronic stress, isolation, lack of sleep, financial worries, traumatic events.

content.heading: Myth vs Fact
content.text: Myth: Strong people don‚Äôt need therapy. Fact: Therapy is a strength, not weakness.

content.heading: Do's & Don'ts
content.text: ‚úî Do: Sleep well, practice mindfulness, talk about feelings. ‚úò Don‚Äôt: Overuse screens, isolate yourself, ignore symptoms.

content.heading: When to See a Doctor
content.text: If sadness lasts more than 2 weeks, panic attacks interfere with life, or suicidal thoughts occur.

content.heading: Daily Checklist
content.text: ‚úî 10 min meditation ‚úî Connect with a friend ‚úî Write gratitude notes ‚úî Take a nature walk

nutrition-diet.title: Nutrition & Diet
nutrition-diet.brief: Balanced diet tips for a healthy body, strong immunity, and better energy.

content.heading: What is Good Nutrition?
content.text: Eating a mix of carbs, proteins, fats, vitamins, and minerals in the right proportions.

content.heading: Why It Matters?
content.text: Good nutrition prevents chronic diseases, boosts immunity, and supports brain function.

content.heading: Unique Fact
content.text: Your gut produces 90% of the body‚Äôs serotonin, the ‚Äòhappiness hormone‚Äô.

content.heading: Risk Factors
content.text: Fast food dependency, nutrient deficiencies, irregular meals, excess sugar.

content.heading: Myth vs Fact
content.text: Myth: Fats are bad. Fact: Healthy fats (avocado, nuts, olive oil) are essential for brain and hormone health.

content.heading: Do's & Don'ts
content.text: ‚úî Do: Eat seasonal fruits, whole grains, drink water. ‚úò Don‚Äôt: Skip breakfast, rely on energy drinks, overeat sugar.

content.heading: When to See a Doctor
content.text: If you notice extreme fatigue, hair loss, frequent illness, or unexplained weight changes.

content.heading: Daily Checklist
content.text: ‚úî 2 fruits ‚úî 3 veggies ‚úî 8 glasses water ‚úî Limit sugar ‚úî Eat home-cooked meals

preventive-care.title: Preventive Care
preventive-care.brief: Stay ahead of illnesses with regular check-ups, vaccines, and healthy habits.

content.heading: What is Preventive Care?
content.text: Healthcare that focuses on avoiding illness before it starts through screenings and vaccinations.

content.heading: Why It Matters?
content.text: Detecting conditions early improves survival and reduces treatment costs.

content.heading: Unique Fact
content.text: Just 5 habits (no smoking, healthy weight, daily exercise, good diet, limited alcohol) prevent 80% of chronic diseases.

content.heading: Risk Factors
content.text: Skipping annual check-ups, ignoring family history, neglecting vaccinations.

content.heading: Myth vs Fact
content.text: Myth: If I feel healthy, I don‚Äôt need check-ups. Fact: Many conditions show no early symptoms.

content.heading: Do's & Don'ts
content.text: ‚úî Do: Schedule regular health screenings. ‚úò Don‚Äôt: Delay vaccines or ignore family history.

content.heading: When to See a Doctor
content.text: Annually for routine exams, or sooner if you notice sudden changes in health.

content.heading: Daily Checklist
content.text: ‚úî Track BP ‚úî Maintain weight ‚úî Sleep 7‚Äì8 hrs ‚úî Stay active ‚úî Eat balanced meals

exercise-fitness.title: Exercise & Fitness
exercise-fitness.brief: Practical fitness routines to stay active, energetic, and strong.

content.heading: Why Exercise Matters?
content.text: Exercise reduces risk of over 35 diseases, boosts brain power, and improves mood.

content.heading: How Much is Enough?
content.text: 150 minutes of aerobic activity + 2 days of strength training weekly.

content.heading: Unique Fact
content.text: Just 10 minutes of brisk walking daily can add up to 7 years to life expectancy.

content.heading: Risk Factors
content.text: Sedentary lifestyle, obesity, poor posture, weak muscles.

content.heading: Myth vs Fact
content.text: Myth: Only intense workouts help. Fact: Even light activities (walking, yoga) give major health benefits.

content.heading: Do's & Don'ts
content.text: ‚úî Do: Warm up before workouts, stay hydrated. ‚úò Don‚Äôt: Overtrain, skip rest days, or exercise on empty stomach.

content.heading: When to See a Doctor
content.text: If you feel chest pain, joint pain, or dizziness during exercise.

content.heading: Daily Checklist
content.text: ‚úî 30 min walk ‚úî 10 min stretch ‚úî 2L water ‚úî 7‚Äì8 hrs sleep ‚úî Take stairs instead of elevator
